csrd.name: CSRD (Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive)
csrd.description: European Union directive requiring companies to report on sustainability matters
csrd.longDescription: The Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) is an EU directive that modernizes and extends the scope of sustainability reporting requirements. It applies to all large companies and all companies listed on regulated markets (except listed micro-enterprises).
whoMustComply: All EU large companies (>250 employees, >€40M turnover, or >€20M balance sheet)
Non-EU companies with significant EU operations
keyRequirements: Report on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) matters
Include scope 1, 2, and 3 greenhouse gas emissions
Get independent assurance of reported information
csrd.timeline: Phased implementation from 2024 to 2028 depending on company size

ghgProtocol.name: GHG Protocol
ghgProtocol.description: Global standard for measuring and managing greenhouse gas emissions
ghgProtocol.longDescription: The Greenhouse Gas Protocol (GHG Protocol) is the most widely used international accounting tool for government and business leaders to understand, quantify, and manage greenhouse gas emissions.
keyPrinciples: Relevance: Ensure the GHG inventory appropriately reflects emissions
Completeness: Account for all emission sources and activities
Consistency: Use consistent methodologies to allow comparisons
Transparency: Address all relevant issues in a factual way
Accuracy: Reduce uncertainties as far as practicable

iso14064.name: ISO 14064
iso14064.description: International standard for greenhouse gas accounting and verification
iso14064.longDescription: ISO 14064 is an international standard that provides clarity and consistency for quantifying, monitoring, reporting and verifying greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.

scope1.name: Scope 1: Direct Emissions
scope1.description: Direct GHG emissions from sources owned or controlled by the company
examples: Natural gas used in office heating
Diesel fuel for company delivery trucks
scope1.whyImportant: These are emissions you have direct control over and can most easily reduce through operational changes.

scope2.name: Scope 2: Energy Indirect Emissions
scope2.description: Indirect GHG emissions from purchased electricity, steam, heating, and cooling
examples: Electricity for office lighting and computers
scope2.whyImportant: While you don't directly create these emissions, you can reduce them by improving energy efficiency and switching to renewable energy sources.

scope3.name: Scope 3: Other Indirect Emissions
scope3.description: All other indirect emissions in your value chain
scope3.whyImportant: Often the largest source of emissions but also the most challenging to measure and influence. CSRD requires reporting on material Scope 3 categories.

co2e.definition: A metric used to compare emissions from various greenhouse gases based on their global warming potential (GWP)
co2e.explanation: Different greenhouse gases have different warming effects. CO2e allows us to express all emissions in terms of the equivalent amount of CO2. For example, 1 ton of methane (CH4) equals 28 tons of CO2e because methane is 28 times more potent than CO2 over 100 years.

gwp.definition: A measure of how much heat a greenhouse gas traps in the atmosphere compared to CO2
gwp.explanation: The GWP is calculated over a specific time period (usually 100 years). CO2 has a GWP of 1. Methane (CH4) has a GWP of 28, meaning it traps 28 times more heat than CO2. Nitrous oxide (N2O) has a GWP of 265.

emissionFactor.definition: A coefficient that quantifies the emissions per unit of activity
emissionFactor.explanation: For example, burning 1 gallon of gasoline produces approximately 8.89 kg of CO2. This '8.89 kg CO2 per gallon' is an emission factor. We use emission factors from trusted sources like EPA and EEA to calculate your emissions.

materialityAssessment.definition: Process of identifying which sustainability topics are most relevant to your business
materialityAssessment.explanation: Under CSRD, you must conduct a double materiality assessment: (1) Impact materiality - how your business affects people and environment, and (2) Financial materiality - how sustainability issues affect your business financially.

baselineYear.definition: A historical reference year against which emissions are tracked over time
baselineYear.explanation: Your baseline year is typically your first year of comprehensive emissions reporting. All future emissions are compared against this baseline to measure progress toward reduction targets.

carbonNeutral.definition: Achieving net zero carbon dioxide emissions
carbonNeutral.explanation: Carbon neutrality is achieved by balancing carbon emissions with carbon removal or simply eliminating carbon emissions altogether. This can be done through carbon offsetting or by reducing emissions to zero.

netZero.definition: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions as close to zero as possible, with remaining emissions absorbed
netZero.explanation: Net zero means cutting emissions by 90-95% and only neutralizing the small remainder that's extremely difficult to eliminate. It's more ambitious than carbon neutral because it requires actual deep decarbonization, not just offsetting.

stationaryCombustion.name: Stationary Combustion
stationaryCombustion.description: Burning fuels in fixed equipment like boilers, furnaces, and generators
dataNeeded: Fuel type (natural gas, diesel, coal, etc.)
Amount of fuel consumed (in volume or weight)
tips: Check utility bills for natural gas consumption
Review fuel delivery receipts for oil or propane

mobileSources.name: Mobile Sources
mobileSources.description: Company-owned or leased vehicles and mobile equipment

electricity.name: Purchased Electricity
tips: Request annual summary from utility provider
Note if you purchase renewable energy

businessTravel.name: Business Travel
businessTravel.description: Employee travel in vehicles not owned by the company
dataNeeded: Mode of travel (air, rail, taxi, rental car)

dataQuality.title: Data Quality Guidance
dataQuality.description: Tips for collecting high-quality emissions data

primary.name: Primary Data
primary.description: Direct measurements specific to your operations

improvementTips: Always use primary data when available
Keep detailed records throughout the reporting period
Set up systems to automatically track key metrics

csrd.name: CSRD (Richtlinie zur Nachhaltigkeitsberichterstattung)
csrd.longDescription: Die Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) ist eine EU-Richtlinie, die die Anforderungen an die Nachhaltigkeitsberichterstattung modernisiert und erweitert.
whoMustComply: Alle großen EU-Unternehmen (>250 Mitarbeiter, >40 Mio. € Umsatz oder >20 Mio. € Bilanzsumme)
keyRequirements: Berichterstattung über Umwelt-, Sozial- und Governance-Themen (ESG)
Einhaltung der European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS)
csrd.timeline: Schrittweise Einführung von 2024 bis 2028 je nach Unternehmensgröße

scope1.name: Scope 1: Direkte Emissionen
scope1.description: Direkte THG-Emissionen aus unternehmenseigenen oder kontrollierten Quellen
scope1.whyImportant: Dies sind Emissionen, die Sie direkt kontrollieren können und am einfachsten durch betriebliche Änderungen reduzieren können.

scope2.name: Scope 2: Indirekte Energieemissionen
scope2.description: Indirekte THG-Emissionen aus eingekauftem Strom, Dampf, Wärme und Kühlung
scope2.whyImportant: Obwohl Sie diese Emissionen nicht direkt erzeugen, können Sie sie durch Verbesserung der Energieeffizienz und Umstellung auf erneuerbare Energien reduzieren.

scope3.name: Scope 3: Sonstige indirekte Emissionen
scope3.description: Alle anderen indirekten Emissionen in Ihrer Wertschöpfungskette
scope3.whyImportant: Oft die größte Emissionsquelle, aber auch am schwierigsten zu messen und zu beeinflussen. CSRD erfordert Berichterstattung über wesentliche Scope 3-Kategorien.

co2e.definition: Metrik zum Vergleich von Emissionen verschiedener Treibhausgase basierend auf ihrem Erderwärmungspotenzial

gwp.definition: Maß dafür, wie viel Wärme ein Treibhausgas im Vergleich zu CO2 in der Atmosphäre speichert

stationaryCombustion.name: Stationäre Verbrennung
stationaryCombustion.description: Verbrennung von Brennstoffen in stationären Anlagen wie Kesseln, Öfen und Generatoren
dataNeeded: Menge des verbrauchten Brennstoffs (Volumen oder Gewicht)
tips: Lieferbelege für Öl oder Propan prüfen

mobileSources.name: Mobile Quellen
mobileSources.description: Unternehmenseigene oder geleaste Fahrzeuge und mobile Geräte

electricity.name: Gekaufter Strom
tips: Notieren, ob Sie erneuerbare Energie beziehen

dataQuality.title: Leitfaden zur Datenqualität

primary.name: Primärdaten
primary.description: Direkte Messungen spezifisch für Ihren Betrieb

improvementTips: Verwenden Sie immer Primärdaten, wenn verfügbar
Führen Sie detaillierte Aufzeichnungen während des gesamten Berichtszeitraums
Richten Sie Systeme zur automatischen Erfassung wichtiger Kennzahlen ein
Überprüfen und validieren Sie Daten regelmäßig
